summary.title: Certificate transparency for Android and JVM

data.name:
Log service
(e.g. Fabric)
data.reasonOutOfScope: Logging is the implementors responsibility and depends on the service used.

data.name: private key
data.description: private key used to sign the loglist.json file

threats.title: Failures blocked from logging
threats.description: An attacker blocking the connection to a logging service can hide a targeted attack on certificate transparency.
threats.mitigation: - Mitigations depend on the logging service used.

threats.title: Fake failures sent to logging service
threats.description: Fake failures sent to logging service can make it look like there are failures that didn't really happen.
threats.mitigation: - Mitigations depend on the logging service used.

threats.title: Malicious certificate presented
threats.description: For a malicious certificate to be trusted, it still has to be signed using a CA in the trust root as well as having at least two valid SCTs, i.e. the loglist will have to be compromised or two log servers private keys known.
threats.mitigation: Log servers determined to not function as expected are actively removed from log lists.

threats.title: Log list changed to allow an otherwise denied connection
threats.description: An attacker could change the log list in memory to add or alter log server entries setting their own public key allowing them to create a certificate with SCTs that would pass validation.
threats.mitigation: - Log list stored with signature at rest and validated when reading to reduce risk of tampering.

threats.title: Set failOnError to false
threats.description: A compromised device could override the 'failOnError' flag in memory causing CT failures to be allowed through.
threats.mitigation:
- Create separate debug & release versions with 'failOnError' only available in the debug variant.
- Library user to implement rooted device detection and handle appropriately.

threats.title: Domain config changed to remove domain from CT checks
threats.description: Changing the domain config in memory can allow an attacker to remove a domain from CT checks resulting in an attacker being able to present certificates that don't pass CT validation.
threats.mitigation: - Have release only build that enforces CT checks for all domains, i.e. so there is no configuration

threats.description: Changing the domain config in memory can allow an attacker to add a domain that has no SCTs to CT checks resulting in calls to that domain failing.
threats.title: Domain config changed to add domain to CT checks
threats.mitigation: - Ensure all domains the app uses through the CT library have SCTs in their certificates.

threats.title: Log list changed to allow an otherwise denied connection
threats.description: An attacker could change the log list in memory to add or alter log server entries setting their own public key allowing them to create a certificate with SCTs that would pass validation.
threats.mitigation: - Log list stored with signature at rest and validated when reading to reduce risk of tampering.

threats.description: An attacker could change the log list in memory to remove log server entries causing SCT verification to fail resulting in a DoS.
threats.title: Log list entries removed to block otherwise valid connections
threats.mitigation: - Log list stored with signature at rest and validated when reading to reduce risk of tampering.

threats.description: For a malicious certificate to be trusted, it still has to be signed using a CA in the trust root as well as having at least two valid SCTs, i.e. the loglist will have to be compromised or two log servers private keys known.
threats.mitigation:
- Detect age of loglist.json and reject if older than a certain age.
- Can be mitigated by ensuring certificates are logged in more than the minimum required number of log servers.
threats.title: Malicious certificate presented
Stale snapshot of loglist.zip can accept rejected log servers
threats.description:
An attacker could present an old snapshot of loglist.zip which will pass validation resulting in the CT library accepting a log server that has since been rejected.

This is only an issue if the certificate presented was generated after the date/time the server was rejected.
threats.mitigation:
- Mitigated by CT checks requiring more than one SCT to validate.
- loglist.json is timestamped which reduces the chance of replay attacks.

threats.title: Block loglist.zip from loading
threats.description: Blocking the loading of loglist.zip will mean validation of SCTs cannot be completed resulting in a DoS.
threats.mitigation: - Store embedded and cached copies of the loglist so clients can continue to work without relying on loading from the network.

threats.title: Out of memory caused by large loglist.json/loglist.sig
threats.description: As the loglist.zip are loaded into memory for processing, if they are large they can cause an out of memory error.
threats.mitigation: - Limit size of loglist.json and loglist.sig loaded into memory.

threats.title: Change in Google's private key breaks signature verification
threats.description: If Google's private key used to sign the loglist.json file is changed then verification will fail causing the CT checks to fail resulting in outgoing connections being rejected and so a DoS.
threats.mitigation:
- Use our own private key so we have more visibility and management of the private key used.
- Monitor the certificate transparency forums to be aware of future key changes.

Partially mitigated by:
- Embedded and cached loglist.json ensure clients can continue to work without relying on loading from the network. However, when the loglist.json is older than 70 days then CT checks are disabled.
- UpdateLogListTask validates the embedded loglist.json when updating the data which will pick up public key changes that have already happened.

threats.title: Log list changed to allow an otherwise denied connection
threats.description: An attacker could change the log list on disk to add or alter log server entries setting their own public key allowing them to create a certificate with SCTs that would pass validation.
threats.mitigation: - Log list stored with signature at rest and validated when reading to reduce risk of tampering.

threats.title: Out of memory caused by large loglist.json/loglist.sig
threats.description: As the loglist.json & loglist.sig are loaded from disk into memory for processing, if they are large they can cause an out of memory error.
threats.mitigation: - Limit size of loglist.json and loglist.sig loaded into memory.

diagrams.title: Threat Model
diagrams.description: Threat Model for the certificate transparency library as implemented on Android
